Creates new laws and revises existing on: Article I of the U.S. Constitution (Article I powers).
Holds the power of the purse (spending) and the power of impeachment (majority vote in House, 2/3 conviction in Senate).
435 voting members, based on population, elected to two-year terms.
100 voting members (two per state), elected to six-year terms.
Carries out and enforces the laws created by the legislative branch.
Article II of the U.S. Constitution (Article II powers).
Veto power over bills passed by Congress (Congress can override with a 2/3 majority in both houses). The power to enforce (or decline to enforce) laws.
Interprets the meaning of laws, resolves disputes, and determines constitutionality.
Article III of the U.S. Constitution.
The power to strike down laws or practices that conflict with the U.S. Constitution (Check on Legislative & Executive).
The trial courts of the federal system.
Intermediate courts that accept cases on appeal from District Courts. Decisions are binding only within their geographic circuit.
Highest court. Decisions are final and binding on all inferior courts. Determines which cases to accept through certiorari.
